answers.author: Zachary Hardy
answers.text:
Even though smartphones, social media, blogs, etc have become important means of communication for those in local government FACE TO FACE communication is still critical. This is especially true when dealing with field staff. A manager that takes the time to speak to field staff in the morning before they pull off to assignments or regularly attends the informal "tailgate meetings" that take place will be most successful communicating with field staff.
Zach Hardy
Assistant Utilities Maintenance Superintendent
City of Olathe, KS
zhardy@olatheks.org

answers.author: Josephine Valencia
answers.text:
For those who are interested, we collect personal email address and forward important email communications.  But overall, I agree that with Mr. Hardy that face to face communication is still critical.  At a former job, we used to print and place in a binder "all user" emails.  I once inserted a flyer that offered $20 cash to the first person to remove the flyer and bring it to me ... no one ever did.   I placed the same flyer on a bulletin board, and it took 4 months for someone to claim that reward.

answers.author: LaKeisha Brown
answers.text:
To improve internal communications between the Human Resources (HR) Section and  Field Operations and Maintenance Division, we launched an internal communication strategy, titled “HR Announcements via Radio Talk Groups.”At 8:30am, 12:00pm, and 3:30pm each work day, field operations and maintenance staff are able to tune into our desginated radio channel from their 800 MHz radios and receive announcements on Recruitment, Labor Relations, Payroll & Benefits, and/or Training, and Safety information. To help get the word out, flyers were posted on bulletin boards in the lunch rooms and break areas at our facilities.
